Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
4D printing is an emerging additive manufacturing technology that combines 3D printing with smart materials. The 4D printed objects can change their shape over time (the 4th dimension) when applying heat, pressure, magnetic field, or moisture to the smart materials. Current 3D printing technology can print objects with a multitude of materials; however, these objects are static, geometrically permanent, and not suitable for multi-functional use. 4D printing with a light responsive shape-changing material is beneficial because light is wireless, easily controllable, and causes a rapid shape change of the smart material. This award supports fundamental research to generate knowledge needed for synthesis of a novel photoactive shape changing polymer (smart material) and integrating this smart material into objects printed using a 3D printing process (fused filament fabrication). 4D printed objects are programmable and can adapt to their environment. Therefore, they can find wider applications, including foldable unmanned aerial vehicles, artificial muscles, grippers, biomedical drug delivery systems, stents, and minimally invasive surgeries.

The research objectives are: (1) to find the relationship between chemical composition of azobenzene shape changing polymer pellets and their physical characteristics (thermal, mechanical, and optical properties); (2) to understand how polymer's composition and extrusion process parameters affect mechanical properties of polymer filaments produced by the extrusion process; and (3) to understand the shape change behavior of 4D printed objects using filaments produced with different polymer composition and extrusion process parameters. To accomplish the first objective, differential scanning calorimetry, UV-Vis spectroscopy, and polarizing light microscopy will be used to measure thermal and optical properties of the polymer pellets. Polymer pellets will also be casted into standard testing bars to measure their mechanical properties through stress-strain experiments, stress induced by UV light exposure, and hardness measurements. To achieve the second objective, extrusion parameters (temperature, material flow rate, and pressure) will be altered, and mechanical properties of produced polymer filaments will be measured. To achieve the third objective, objects will be printed using filaments produced with different polymer composition and extrusion process parameters. Percentage volume contraction, reversibility, bending speed, bending angle, and mechanical work output (shape change during a period of time over which stress is applied) of these printed objects will be measured with different levels of light input (intensity). The knowledge gained from this research can be useful in developing other 4D printing processes (such as stereolithography and selective-powder-sintering) using photoactive smart materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project is to 3D print a photo-sensitive shape-changing polymer (SCP) that can change its shape reversibly when exposed to light. Current 3D printing technology can print objects with a multitude of materials; however, these objects are static, geometrically permanent, and not suitable for multi-functional use. This research explores a new technology called 4D printing, which is 3D printing a material that can change in shape or property of a material over time when it is exposed to external stimuli: temperature, water, pH levels, or light.  Light as an activation source is chosen because it is abundant, easily controllable, wireless, clean, causes rapid shape change of the smart material, and light-reactive smart materials possess reversible shape change. This award supports fundamental research to generate knowledge needed for synthesis of a novel photoactive shape changing polymer (smart material) and integrating this smart material into objects printed with a 4D printing process using piston extrusion.

Current 4D printing methods use heat, water, or stress as activation methods. The use of light as a photochemical reaction has not been seen in 4D printing methods. The use of azobenzene as a photochemical SCP presents promising additions to area of 4D printing because azobenzene is fast reacting and also possesses reversible shape change. Most 4D printed materials require mechanical deformation, usually through human interaction in order to change the material to a temporary shape. However, azobenzene only needs light to induce shape change. The intensity and polarity of light on the material can induce different bending speeds, angles, and bending directions.  This is promising when shape change is required in areas where humans do not have access to such as extreme environments: oceans, space, polar environments, and internal biological bodies. This could also allow for the automation of actuated shape changing devices that respond to their environment.

The synthesis of a 3D printable azobenzene SCP will add to the area of 4D printing since a photo-isomerizable 4D printable material has not been reported yet. If successful, this material and technique may be used in areas of product design and microfabrication. Microfabricated parts that require many stages make an actuating part could be replaced with our bilayer films that reduces the number of required moving parts and simplifies the system.

The project will help streamline the manufacturing process of products. Embedding the shape changing and actuation directly into the materials will reduce the number of required parts in a product. This reduces the number materials, the amount of waste, and the amount of expenses for products. Light sensitive materials may also automate commercial items or items part of the everyday life. Roofs or blinds could have shape memory properties and respond to sunlight that allow for ventilation or create shade. Solar panels could have light responsive materials that naturally follow and track the trajectory of the sun without the need for motors or processors. Smaller devices that require actuation could have our materials installed, which would reduce the number of tiny moving mechanical parts.

The research on 4D Printing of Photoactive Azobenzene Shape Memory Polymers has been presented at several poster sessions for incoming mechanical engineering undergraduate students at Drexel University. The poster presents information on the 3D printing process, an introduction to smart materials and 4D printing, the synthesis of the azobenzene SMP, and the photomechanical behavior behind the azobenzene SMP. A review paper was written and accepted at Taylor and Francis, Virtual Printing and Prototyping, which presents Current status of 4D printing technology and the potential of light-reactive smart materials as 4D printable materials. A second paper, which discusses 4D Printed Polylactic acid (PLA) and the shape-memory properties it possesses was submitted and accepted at Taylor and Francis, Virtual Printing and Prototyping. A paper was accepted by ACS applied materials & interfaces on the Photoactivated Polymeric Bilayer Actuators Fabricated via 3-D Printing. A patent application has been filed to the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (“USPTO”) for “Externally Activated Shape Changing Device” on June 19th, 2019. Serial No. 16/432,664. Leist, S. K. (2017). Design of a 4D Printing System Using Thermal Sensitive Smart Materials and Photoactivated Shape Changing Polymers (Doctoral dissertation, Drexel University). Hagaman, D. (2018). Light-Driven Polymeric Bilayer Actuators Fabricated by 3-D Printing (Doctoral dissertation, Drexel University).

Modified by: Jack Zhou

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The main goal of this project is to 3D print a photo-sensitive shape-changing polymer (SCP) that can change its shape reversibly when exposed to light. Current 3D printing technology can print objects with a multitude of materials; however, these objects are static, geometrically permanent, and not suitable for multi-functional use. This research explores a new technology called 4D printing, which is 3D printing a material that can change in shape or property of a material over time when it is exposed to external stimuli: temperature, water, pH levels, or light. This award supports fundamental research to generate knowledge needed for synthesis of a novel photoactive shape changing polymer (smart material) and integrating this smart material into objects printed with a 4D printing process using piston extrusion. Current 4D printing methods use heat, water, or stress as activation methods. The use of light as a photochemical reaction has not been seen in 4D printing methods. The use of azobenzene as a photochemical SCP presents promising additions to area of 4D printing because azobenzene is fast reacting and also possesses reversible shape change. Most 4D printed materials require mechanical deformation, usually through human interaction in order to change the material to a temporary shape. However, azobenzene only needs light to induce shape change. The intensity and polarity of light on the material can induce different bending speeds, angles, and bending directions. If successful, this material and technique may be used in areas of product design and microfabrication. Smaller devices that require actuation could have our materials installed, which would reduce the number of tiny moving mechanical parts.
